motion.info_slide:
Below are extra information provided by Brendo, which may include Brendo's arguments:

Animal testing is commonly used to test products such as drugs. The argument is that testing on animals is very similar to testing on humans. I disagree and believe that animal testing does not work as much as people believe it does.

speech.content:
Animal testing has proven to be uneffective and a complete waste of taxpayers money. Most of the time, the test performed on rats and other animals did not relate to human trials at all. In one dramatic case, a test worked perfectly on animals and was authorised for human testing. That test ended up with all of those people in hospital with emergency treatment.

I propose an alternative. Instead of testing on animals, test on humans. If you want a product that works on humans, test a product on humans. The more dangerous products will be tested on death row inmates. If the product works, then that is a big leap forward for that product being distributed. If it failed, then nothing of high value was lost since that person was going to die anyway.

Well for a start yes it might not relate to humans and because it worked on as per say rats and not on humans it would only be a small amount of people that it didn"t work and it"s only been a small handful that it hasn"t worked. Most animals they do testing on are rats and smaller animals which there organs and stuff work the same as us humans so most of the time when they want to do testing they do it on smaller animals which will work when they release it but they don"t release it after one test they do multiple test for months and months.

With the fact you should test it on humans, The reason they don"t do it on humans because a person has to be willing to give it to them and people in the prison on death row might not have the current disease that they need for testing which if it"s import like cancer you want to make it quick to find a cure to that more people don"t die. If you have people on death row is takes years sometimes till they get killed so if they finally find a cure they won"t be able to test if it the guy doesn"t have cancer so it defeats the purpose.

Therefore if they test if on rats and smaller animals they can see if it might work, Not to say it will it might then people who get the drug will have to sign a agreement saying there could be side effects during the testing and you could die but that"s where the animals come in so they at least know that yes in some cases it might not be safe but they can test it fries for months to make sure that should not cause any harm.

It is not a small amount of people it did not work on, The tests done on rats and other animals failed to work on humans over 80% of the time. That means over 80% of research is wasted and the whole process starts again. Because of this, A large amount of money is also wasted because the research was completely useless.

As for finding people to test on. Death row inmates can choose either the death penalty, Or human experimentation. They will be given a short explanation as to how the experiment can benefit society. Either way, They will die. However this system allows for the science industry to move forward significantly as they are able to test products a lot more accurately.

When you stated that the reason they do not test on humans is because the human may not have the disease, The same goes for rats. The scientist gives the rat the disease, Then proceeds to perform experiments on that rat. For humans, The scientist would give the death row inmate the disease in order to start the experiment. Neither the rat or the human needs to already have the disease in order to begin an experiment.

This new procedure may cost more, But the benefit of more accurate results would benefit society dramatically.

For a start I would like I you to find the statistics for the first point that you made since most of the trials that get tested don"t work since they haven"t found the proper drug to work and would not be a large waste of money since if they end up finding a cure to cancer I don"t think testing on an animal would be as bad.

Yes I understand that you can choose your death on death row and they have a choice on what they want done, But if we are looking at Australia you won"t be able to find anyone to kill or who will be willing to take it because we have lots of research labs in Australia but the only thing we can test it on is animals.

But if the scientists gave the disease to an death row inmate then they would have to choose it they might not want to do it, Because as you said they have the right to choose what they want to get done.

The statistics from my previous statement came from Steve Perrin. He wrote multiple articles about animal testing. A direct quote from one of his article reads, "more than 80% of potential therapeutics fail when tested in people. "

The link for the article can be found here.\
<https://www>.[nature.com/news/preclinical-research-make-mouse-studies-work-1.14913](http://nature.com/news/preclinical-research-make-mouse-studies-work-1.14913)

He follows this stating that, "The series of clinical trials for a potential therapy can cost hundreds of millions of dollars. "

The article clearly shows that hundreds of millions of dollars are spent on research when only 20% of that research can be used. 80% of those funds are simply washed away and wasted because rats are not humans.

Who thought it would be a good idea to test on animals in order to get results on humans? Rats and humans are two completely different creatures. If you wanted to get results for humans, Test on humans. It is that simple.

The reason you do testing on animals is because they have the same organ structure so most of the time when you test it on animals it works and yes they might not work all the time on humans but that"s why they can get it right the first time.

Well most results come up the exact same just have different affects on different people in my opinion it"s fine to do testing on animals it"s only been done on rats and smaller animals with the same type of organs and blood as humans.

pro: Testing on humans is feasible and is a standard practice in clinical trials, though it is subject to ethical considerations and regulations.
Testing on death row inmates can be limited by ethical concerns and legal restrictions, not solely by the presence of specific diseases.

The Pro argument is more persuasive because it highlights the necessity of animal trials due to ethical restrictions on human testing, which is a widely accepted principle in research ethics. The Con argument, while interesting, suggests a controversial and ethically questionable approach that may not be widely supported or accepted, making it less compelling.

The Pro argument highlights a significant ethical concern regarding the health conditions of death row inmates, suggesting that their varied health issues may compromise the validity of test results. This raises important questions about the reliability and ethical implications of using such individuals for testing. In contrast, the Con argument lacks sufficient justification for why death row inmates would be a more accurate substitute for human testing, making it less persuasive overall.

The Pro argument highlights a significant concern regarding the potential impact on medical progress, which resonates with the importance of advancing healthcare. In contrast, while the Con argument raises a valid point about taxpayer waste, it does not directly address the implications of slowing down medical advancements, making it less compelling in the context of overall societal benefits.

The Pro argument effectively highlights the ethical constraints surrounding human testing, which justifies the necessity of animal trials as a means to ensure safety and efficacy before human trials. The Con argument, while emphasizing the relevance of human trials, does not adequately address the ethical implications of bypassing animal testing, making it less persuasive in the context of safety and ethical considerations.

The Pro argument highlights a significant concern regarding the health conditions of death row inmates, which raises questions about the validity and reliability of the test results. This argument addresses a practical issue that could undermine the ethical justification of testing. The Con argument lacks a strong ethical framework or justification for why testing on potentially compromised subjects is acceptable, making it less persuasive overall.

The pro argument presents a clear benefit of animal testing by emphasizing its role in identifying potential side effects, which is crucial for ensuring human safety. In contrast, the con argument, while highlighting the need for alternative methods, does not provide a strong rationale for why these methods are superior or how they would effectively replace animal testing. The pro argument is more directly tied to the safety and efficacy of medical treatments.
con: While animal testing has limitations, it has also contributed to many medical advancements and is often considered a necessary step in research.
Volunteer-based human testing raises significant ethical concerns regarding consent, safety, and exploitation.
There is no established evidence that testing on death row inmates is a viable or ethical alternative to animal trials.
N/A
N/A
There is no scientific consensus or ethical justification supporting the use of death row inmates as substitutes for human testing.
Providing choices for death row inmates does not ethically justify human trials, as ethical standards for human experimentation require informed consent and cannot be based on coercive circumstances.
N/A
Animal testing is often necessary for safety and efficacy before human trials can ethically occur.
Ethical justification for testing on death row inmates is highly contested and generally considered problematic due to issues of consent and exploitation.

The Con argument is more persuasive because it emphasizes the importance of human trials in advancing health outcomes, which is a fundamental goal of medical research. The Pro argument, while highlighting a logistical issue, does not address the critical need for human trials and their potential benefits, making it less compelling in the context of the overall importance of medical advancements.

The Con argument presents a counterpoint that emphasizes the ethical feasibility and potential benefits of volunteer-based human testing, which can yield more relevant data. In contrast, the Pro argument lacks depth and does not address the ethical considerations or potential methods for conducting human testing, making it less persuasive overall.

The Con argument presents a clear benefit of testing on death row inmates by highlighting its potential to replace ineffective animal trials and reduce taxpayer waste. This provides a practical rationale for the testing, making it more persuasive. In contrast, the Pro argument lacks depth and does not effectively counter the potential benefits outlined in the Con argument.

The Con argument is more persuasive because it emphasizes the importance of ensuring that research directly benefits human health, which is a critical consideration in medical research. While the Pro argument acknowledges the role of animal testing, it does not address the potential ethical concerns or the limitations of animal models in translating results to humans. The Con argument presents a clearer focus on human welfare and the need for relevant outcomes.

The Con argument presents a clear statistic that highlights the ineffectiveness of animal testing in translating to human health benefits, which is a strong point against the practice. In contrast, the Pro argument lacks specific evidence or statistics to support the claim that animal testing is essential, making it less persuasive overall.

The Con argument is more persuasive because it directly addresses a critical flaw in the Pro argument by highlighting the lack of translation from animal testing to human efficacy. While the Pro argument asserts the necessity of animal testing, it does not sufficiently counter the significant concern that the results may not be applicable to humans, which undermines its overall effectiveness.

The Con argument presents a strong statistical claim that highlights the inefficacy of animal testing in translating to human health benefits, which undermines the Pro argument's assertion of successful medical advancements. The specific percentage adds credibility and weight to the Con position, making it more persuasive overall.

The Con argument highlights a significant issue with animal testing: the lack of applicability of results to humans. This raises concerns about the efficiency and relevance of research, making it a strong point against animal testing. In contrast, the Pro argument assumes that decreasing animal testing will inherently slow medical progress without addressing the potential for alternative methods that could be more effective and relevant.

The Con argument is more persuasive because it presents a rationale for using death row inmates as a substitute for human testing, suggesting that they may provide a more accurate representation of human responses. In contrast, the Pro argument lacks depth and does not effectively address the potential benefits or ethical considerations of testing on this population. It merely states a limitation without providing a compelling reason against the practice.

The Con argument is more persuasive because it emphasizes the importance of human trials in providing relevant data for human health, which is a critical consideration in medical research. The Pro argument, while highlighting a logistical issue, does not address the ethical implications or the potential benefits of prioritizing human trials over animal testing.

The Con argument directly addresses a critical flaw in the Pro argument by highlighting that the success of animal testing does not guarantee its effectiveness for humans. This challenges the validity of the Pro argument's claim about historical success, making it more persuasive.

The Con argument directly addresses a critical flaw in the Pro argument by highlighting that despite similarities, the results from animal testing often do not apply to humans. This undermines the Pro argument's assumption that animal similarities guarantee effective outcomes in human medicine.

The Con argument is more persuasive because it emphasizes the importance of relevance in testing, suggesting that human trials provide more applicable results for human health outcomes compared to animal testing. The Pro argument lacks depth and does not address the potential benefits of human trials, making it less compelling.

The Con argument presents a broader ethical perspective that can be compelling in discussions about medical testing and the moral implications of using vulnerable populations. In contrast, the Pro argument is limited in scope, focusing on a logistical issue rather than addressing the ethical considerations of testing on death row inmates.

The Con argument highlights a significant issue regarding the relevance of animal testing to human outcomes, which undermines the justification for its necessity in medical research. This point raises doubts about the effectiveness of animal testing, making it more persuasive than the Pro argument, which does not address the potential shortcomings of animal testing.
